title: Semantics and Complexity of SPARQL

introducer: Natasha Noy, Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research
author: Jorge Pérez, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile

We have 24 papers that has sparkle in the title.
Yes, that gives you an idea of the papers that are actually about sparkle and in the next five years from 2000 Eleven 2016.

We have 108 papers with sparkle in the title, so there's a huge number of papers, but not only that, and which is more interesting is that now we have sparkle papers in several other major conferences.

The title about sparkle.

In general there are nine ICD ICT papers, 8 SIGMOD pods, paper even for tripling AI papers.

As a final comment.
There is one of these examples that show that practice can be benefit by a formal approach and a clean formalization can be very useful because it could clarify corner cases.
It can help in implementation process, and it can actually simplify things, yes.
This is maybe the most important part of good formalization.

Things never complicates things.

We shouldn't wait until having a final specification.

So semantic web research has this nice interaction between theory and practice, and this is very cool and we should continue doing that.
So thank you to the committee and thank you very much for your attention.
